title: Console Graphics ScreenBuffers
body: First of all, thank you very much for your console improvements!

comments.body: just a related random, and for added historical feel-good-tingles, does anyone remember running this: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VDMSound

even more awesome than this idea, as an extension, embed dosbox-style emulation of old-skool 8 and 16bit DOS APIs that would allow to seamlessly use a 16bit DOS program (or game) and fiddle with it's DOS-native STDIN and STDOUT file handles with a powershell script driving a XAML/.NET/Universal app all communicating with web APIs. Just because we have 64bit megamachines doesn't mean we want 16bit emulated code eschewed into an add-on runtime (dosbox or hardware-virtualisation) which doesn't really do anything to allow interoperation of hosted programmes. </Pie-In-The-Sky>

EDIT: After double-checking, I saw that the "bug concerning mapping the created screenbuffer into the client address space" was fixed in Windows 8+, so that it only exists in Windows 7 (it would need a dedicated MS patch). However in Windows 7 and Windows 8+ there is still this NtVdmControl call. I personally think this check is totally useless (that verifies whether the caller is a VDM process or not), because from my point-of-view, since conhost.exe runs with the same rights as the client console app, there is no way (normally) to possibly make the whole system crash by exploiting some vulnerability in the console graphics screenbuffers, contrary to what might was possible in Windows <= Vista when the console subsystem was hosted in winsrv.dll/csrss.exe ...
